texts.shortText: Distinctive, large, upright species with very dark-green, flaccid, spongy lobes that branch dichotomously.
Whole structure can be as much as 1000 mm tall. Individual lobes about 2 mm thick and up to 240 mm wide.

Global: Previously reported as endemic to South Africa, but subsequently recorded from Senegal and Korea (seems unlikely these records are of the same species though).

Local/Regional: Table Bay to Southern KwaZulu-Natal.

Distinctive and unusually large species found in lowshore pools and on shallow reefs, most common on south coast. Often encrusted by patches of the Flat red alga Placophora binderi, as seen on image below.

Can reproduce asexually by fragmentation allowing it to rapidly colonise new areas. Sexual reproduction in this genus is variable and complex and can involve production of parthenogenetically developing ‘swarmer cells’, or separate males and females producing spores from reproductive structures on the surfaces of the utricles.
The only flat-bladed, erect Codium in the region.
